Join Keys

NEST CoreDev

2022-04-20

join-keys.Rmd

Keys

Each table passed into teal can have a set of keys that inform teal about its structure and relation to other tables. teal allows specifying: - columns consisting the primary key - merge keys, a concept similar to SQLs foreign key.

Usually, an application developer needs to specify the keys manually, but in case of datasets named according to the ADaM standard, teal can assign the keys on its own. Refer to vignette("including-adam-data-in-teal") for more information.

Primary key

Using the keys argument to the dataset (or for DDL a dataset_connector) function we can specify column(s) of the dataset which together uniquely identify rows in the dataset. teal throws an error if it finds at least two rows sharing all the same values of the primary key columns.

library(teal)
## Loading required package: shiny
## Loading required package: teal.data
## Loading required package: teal.transform
## Loading required package: magrittr
## 
## You are using teal version 0.11.1.9002
library(teal.data)
library(dplyr)
## 
## Attaching package: 'dplyr'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     filter, lag
## The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
## 
##     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
iris_with_keys <- mutate(iris, id = factor(row_number()))

app <- init(
  data = teal_data(
    dataset("IRIS",
      iris_with_keys,
      code = "IRIS <- iris %>% mutate(id = factor(row_number()))",
      keys = c("id")
    ),
    dataset("CARS", mtcars, code = "CARS <- mtcars")
  ),
  modules = modules(
    example_module()
  )
)

if (interactive()) shinyApp(app$ui, app$server)

Merge keys

When passing multiple datasets to the [teal.data::cdisc_data()] function, dataset relationship are set using [teal.data::join_keys()] and [teal.data::join_key()] and these are used to merge datasets together within teal apps. For users familiar with SQL database schemas, these relationships are symmetric and not as strict as SQL foreign key relationships as teal does not validate whether the values inserted into foreign key columns are present in the parent table.

For example:

library(teal)

data_1 <- data.frame(X = factor(1:10), Y = 21:30, Z = 1:10)
data_2 <- data.frame(W = factor(10:1), V = factor(5:14), M = rep(1:5, 2))
data_3 <- data.frame(V = factor(5:14), T = 4)

data <- teal_data(
  dataset("D1", data_1, code = "D1 <- data.frame(X = factor(1:10), Y = 21:30, Z = 1:10)"),
  dataset("D2", data_2, code = "D2 <- data.frame(W = factor(10:1), V = factor(5:14), M = rep(1:5, 2))"),
  dataset("D3", data_3, code = "D3 <- data.frame(V = factor(5:14), T = 4)"),
  join_keys = join_keys(
    join_key("D1", "D2", c("X" = "W")),
    join_key("D2", "D3", c("V" = "V"))
  )
)

The [teal.data::join_keys()] function is used to specify keys:

  • [teal.data::join_keys()] is a collection of multiple [teal.data::join_key()] entries
  • [teal.data::join_key()] specifies the relation between two datasets:
    • dataset_1, dataset_2 - name of two datasets
    • key - (optionally) named vector of column names

Note that it is assumed that join keys are symmetric, i.e. join_key("x", "y", "x_col" = "y_col") will enable merge from “x” to “y” and vice versa.
